ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Cool new style for essays. Learned how to plan and write a paper in less than 12 hours. Slurry of insights about pretty random political thinkers.
Analyzing history far removed from my time and experience.

This course gave me a general overview of ancient Greek and Roman history, the earliest political thought, and the development of the Abrahamic religions. The variety of texts and formats made me think about new (to me, but really old) ways to conceive of history and politics. And, although we didn't talk much about writing, it also helped me get used to the style of college essays.

This class was a great opportunity to enhance critical writing and readings abilities. Certainly left course with a much better understanding of the relationship between history and politics and the influence of personal histories on our understanding of the concept and practice of history as we teach and learn it today.
How to better manage my time, as well as how to be a more efficient writer.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Teaching the Bible was kind of out-of-place. Maybe could have loosened on the need to teach works in order and alternated the histories and political thought works more.
Well-organized curriculum and accompanying lectures. Biggest weakness is that the lectures are on Fridays, after all the corresponding seminars.

Strengths: You get a sense of a long stretch of history and some of the major intellectual forces in the Western tradition, including religious ones. The lectures are amazing, even if they came too late in the week to really frame seminar discussions. Weaknesses: You move fast and aren't able to form a full, clear idea of one thinker before rushing to the next one. The historical readings have lots of little excerpts, so, for the continuity of the reading experience, I wonder if the assigned passages could involve less jumping around, even at the expense of certain moments.

Strengths: Essay feedback; Pre-seminar questions; Professor Wilford clearly genuinely cares about each of her students and is always willing to set up office hours and go out of her way to help students.
Strengths: Taking this course definitely makes you a much stronger writer, and the intensity of the reading load means that your time management becomes much better over the course of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but don't do alongside another hard course. The papers end up taking up most of your time.
If you are very interested in growing as a reader and writer then I think this would be a good course to take!
I would recommend this course to another student if they were genuinely interested in the subject material.
